My parents told me about Mr. Common Sense early in my life and told me I would do well to call on him when making decisions. It seems he was always around in my early years but less and less as time passed by. Today I read his obituary. Please join me in a moment of silence in remembrance. For Common Sense has served us all so well for so many generations.

Obituary
Common Sense

Today we mourn the passing of a beloved old friend, Common Sense, who has been with us for many years. No one knows for sure how old he was since his birth records were long ago lost in bureaucratic red tape. He will be remembered as having cultivated such valuable lessons as knowing when to come in out of the rain, why the early bird gets the worm, why life isn't always fair, and how, on occasion, maybe it was my fault.

Common Sense lived by simple, sound financial policies (don't spend more than you earn) and reliable parenting strategies (adults, not children are in charge). His health began to deteriorate rapidly when well intentioned but overbearing regulations were set in place. Reports of a six-year-old boy charged with sexual harassment for kissing a classmate; teens suspended from school for using mouthwash after lunch; and a teacher fired for reprimanding an unruly student, only worsened his condition.

Common Sense lost ground when parents attacked teachers for doing the job they themselves failed to do in disciplining their unruly children. It declined even further when schools were required to get parental consent to administer aspirin, sun lotion or a sticky plaster to a student; but could not inform the parents when a student became pregnant and wanted to have an abortion.

Common Sense lost the will to live as the Ten Commandments became contraband; churches became businesses; and criminals received better treatment than their victims. Common Sense took a beating when you couldn't defend yourself from a burglar in your own home and the burglar can sue you for assault.

Common Sense finally gave up the will to live, after a woman failed to realize that a steaming cup of coffee was hot. She spilled a little in her lap, and was promptly awarded a huge settlement.

Common Sense was preceded in death by his parents, Truth and Trust; his wife, Discretion; his daughter, Responsibility; and his son, Reason. He is survived by three stepbrothers; I Know my Rights, Someone Else is to Blame, and I'm a Victim.

Not many attended his funeral because so few realized he was gone.

I guess I'll try and make the most of it.  honestly, I should tell the manager that he's an idiot and take the job myself.  Lord knows I could do it and I need the money.  

          that was supposed to be a short update.  oh well, guess I kinda ranted there.  in other news, both Nick and Kevin work at Sears now and in the electronics department no less.  Our schedules are bound to overlap sometime, already did once with Nick.  so that'll be nice I hope.  
oh yeah, I forgot the initial thought that led to this update.  I've noticed that I've begun to slack off at work.  not intentionally, I just notice that since the team got split up and with kirk being a stupid twat, I've had less work to do and I've begun dragging my feet a bit when getting it done.  Maybe it's because back when we worked together I felt I had this obligation to the rest of the team to do my best, or I did my best because I was part of a team.  Now, I feel nothing for this job.  By all means I don't hate it, or even dislike it.  I just feel like I've lost part of this job that made me look forward to going to work everyday.  I dunno.  comments and concerns welcomed.

Always been there to shoot the guy coming up from behind on my right when I'm pinned down by opposing fire.  You've always been around, even when I didn't want you to be.  I'll miss you buddy.  You're my best friend, and I love you.

So summer's almost over and I have $300 dollars (worked a security job for a weekend) and a lifetime of memories to show for it.  I didn't mind going up to Canada all summer....  scratch that.  I minded the hell out of it.  Especially last year.  I hated the thought of not being able to spend my last high school summer with my friends, not be able to reminisce with them about memories that I would have been a part of, and not to have been able to tell that special someone just how much she meant to me and to spend my last summer with her, even if she didn't return my feelings.  It was my last chance.

But that was last summer, and it wasn't like I went to a prison camp or anything.  I made a lot of new friends up there and made a lot of good memories.  and was reunited with them again this summer, and managed to make a few more friends along the way.  It wasn't so hard this time since I had started a new beginning at the end of last summer.  

I went to Slippery Rock University and majored in computer science.  Boy was that dumb.  The program was sketchy, and I was only able to take one computer class per semester for the next 4 years. If you knew me in high school, you'd know that I like my computer classes.  I took every one available in the school.  But I guess it doesn't matter now.  I did something stupid that I won't say here, but it involves my next post when I make it(Edit: or the one after that since I wrote something I want to post in here before I managed to write the other one.).  because of that event, I'm not allowed back for a little while.  But, no matter.  

It was probably the best thing that could have happened to me.  I'm now no longer going back to SRU.  I'm now going to CCBC and unlike Slippery Rock, I am taking 4 computer classes.  I'll be sort of returning to my old life, seeing my old friends, starting over, though it won't be where I left off.  I didn't realize it until a while ago, but I've apparently grown up a lot this year.  Smarter, wiser, more confident, and I know I'm not the only one.  Everyone else I haven't seen for a year has grown up too, and I wonder how much everyone's changed, hopefully not too much or for the worse.

I biggest worry is that even though I want to see them all again, I left them.  they all still had each other, why should they be interested in being in my life again, after I abandoned the best thing I ever had in pursuit of higher education?








Because I'm awesome.  That's why.

Peace out.

I just had a realization.
I take a few history classes.  In them, I learn about history, hence the title of the class.  I learn about all these different kingdoms and empires and hear about these kings and pharaohs and emperors and what they did.  Then it hit me.  These men were like gods to these people.  people worshiped them.  They were the most important person in the world to millions.  And now, what did they leave behind? For those of you who have been living under a rock, have no interest in my life, have Alzheimer's disease, or are just stupid, I somehow got into college.  I go to Slippery Rock University and I major in computer science.  I moved in a few days ago.

I arrived at Slippery Rock at 9:17 AM on Friday, August 26, 2005.  It was hectic.  We pull up to my residence hall, named Bard(DnD reference maybe?), and a bunch of people in bright yellowish green t-shirts come up to our car and start grabbing everything they can out of there.  If you know me, you know I'm a little self conscious about people touching my stuff, especially strangers.  in a shirt so bright you can see it a half a mile away, day or night. Getting paranoid at this point, I sign in,  my dad has gotten back from parking the car, and my cousin Chris arrived to help me carry stuff up.

Miraculously, nothing of mine got stolen.  We head up to the room, and we find out that my sister Mindy's room is bigger.  and she's living alone.  and she gets a comfy chair.  We bring all of my stuff in, rearrange some stuff, and make the play habitable.  The roommate's not here... yet.  I hooked up my computer and immediately wept(really, I wept) at the speed of a fiber optic T3 connection.  Especially when no one else had their's hooked up yet because people are stupid and think that the internet just magically appears in front of them on their computers without ethernet cables.  Idiots.

My dad goes off in search of a screwdriver because the room isn't designed very well, and Chris and I goof off and make impersonations and stupid stuff like that while I unpacked my stuff.  My dad came back after a long ass time.  If you don't want to read about my dad's journey to find a screwdriver, go to the next paragraph which is a good bit and has my roommate in it.  First, he went to the CA(community adviser) of my floor, and was told to go to the front desk person.  So he goes down there, stands in line for a while, and then that person says that she has no idea what he's talking about, and that she doesn't have one.  So my dad leaves and decides to go to Dodds, the residence hall Mindy is staying in to get her screwdriver.  He goes in and gets locked in the stairwell.  Why he was using the stairs to go up to the seventh floor is beyond me.  He should of just bummed a ride on the elevator.  Anyway, someone finally lets him out, and he goes to Mindy's room and wait a little while for her to show up in the hall.  If you didn't know, Mindy's a CA, so she's busy on moving day, but she gets to stay free and gets her own room.  I've already started filling out the appropriate application forms.  anyway, getting back on track,  My dad asks Mindy for a screwdriver, so Mindy goes to look for it.  Then she realizes that she let the CA of another floor borrow it.  So they go down and get it, my dad leaves, Mindy says goodbye, and my dad returns to the room.

Now my roommate shows up.  His name is Jamie, he's a political science major, a republican, from York, and drove quite a way to get here.  I'll do a full analysis of him later. Episode 1 is hard. It was (in my opinion, at least) horrible on virtually all levels. Still, if I had to pick one element out of all of them, it would be midichlorians. When they took the Force and turned it into something mechanical and scientific, something that could be rated and measured, they negated the element that separated Star Wars from other science fiction sagas.

Episode II was a vast improvement over the Phantom Menace, this I will grant you. It's also far easier to pick a single element that damaged the movies. Episode III. Reserved. Hopefully not to be used.

Does anyone know why people write LiveJournals? Perhaps we're obsessed with the gossip in our immediate social group, or perhaps there is a natural inclination to the insight of other people's lives. Nevertheless, I'm utilizing idiosyncratically arranged lines of twenty-six phonetic symbols, ten numbers, and about eight punctuation marks, to perform telepathy. Sort of. There's something in my mind, something I thought at a given point or time, and then I put it here. After I put it here, you put it in your mind, giving you the same thoughts I had. So we essentially just experienced a telepathic exchange of thought, right?

Ok, so maybe a LiveJournal isn't so glorious as telepathy.

Maybe you want to know what I'm really doing, and it's not just messing with your head, telepathically or otherwise. Like children fear the dark, I fear something that cannot be touched. I fear being forgotten. Old photo albums are meaningless if you don't remember who's in them. A hollow face in a picture frame says nothing. To remember someone, there has to be meaning behind it. Much like all these idiosyncratically arranged lines of twenty-six phonetic symbols, ten numbers, and about eight punctuation marks are useless if you can't remember what it means.

So someday when I'm gone, I want you to read this, and remember the words I wrote were me.
